Description: Corinthian terracotta doll of a female dancer. Arm from a jointed doll. String hole for attaching arms would join at shoulders. Pressed into a one-piece mould with a plain flat, roughly finished back. White coating with red-pink paint on arms. Fine red-beige clay.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Close 5th century BC parallels found at Kamiros, Rhodes and Cyrenaica attributed to Corinth by Higgins (Higgins 1970, nos. 914, 945). Doll figures dated 480 to 450 BC have been found at Rhodes, Beoetia, Cyrenaica, and Taranto (Mollard-Besques 1954, 38, no. C93, C159, C215, C566). Mollard-Besques, S. 1954. Catalogue raisonnédes figurines et reliefs en terre-cuite Grecs Étrusques et Romains I: Époques Préhellénique Géométrique, Archaïque et Classique. Paris: Musée National du Louvre.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.391) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4568 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
